summary: A grand jury subpoena issued by the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York to Wells Fargo Bank, demanding extensive financial records for accounts from January 1, 2019 onward. The subpoena is part of an investigation into alleged violations of federal statutes including bribery, conspiracy, false statements, and obstruction. It includes detailed instructions for document production and a procedure for reimbursement.

persons.name: Geoffrey S. Berman
persons.context: Issued and signed the grand jury subpoena as the United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York.

persons.name: Ed Tyrrell
persons.role: Government Official (likely in Accounts Payable or Finance)
persons.context: Referenced as the contact for advance permission if estimated reimbursement costs exceed $500.

events.title: Grand Jury Appearance Date for Wells Fargo
events.description: The date by which Wells Fargo Bank was commanded to appear before a grand jury or produce the requested financial records.

events.title: Subpoena Issuance
events.description: The date the grand jury subpoena was issued and signed by U.S. Attorney Geoffrey S. Berman.

locations: United States Courthouse, 40 Foley Square, Room 220, Manhattan, New York, NY
U.S. Attorney's Office, 1 St. Andrew's Plaza, New York, NY 10007
Wells Fargo Bank, N.A., Summons and Subpoenas Department, P.O. Box 1416, Charlotte, NC 28201
U.S. Attorney's Office - SDNY Accounts Payable, 86 Chambers Street, 3rd floor, New York, NY 10007
keyFacts: The subpoena seeks all financial records (account documents, statements, wire transfers, checks, etc.) for specific accounts from January 1, 2019, onward, indicating an active investigation into financial activity around that time.

The investigation involves alleged violations of multiple federal statutes: 18 U.S.C. §§ 201 (bribery), 371 (conspiracy), 1001 (false statements), 1346 (honest services fraud), 1519 (destruction/alteration of records), and 2 (aiding and abetting).
The subpoena is directed at Wells Fargo Bank, suggesting the investigation targets an individual or entity holding accounts at that institution.
The document includes a detailed 'Rider' specifying the exact format for electronic production of transaction data, showing the investigation's focus on tracing financial flows.

A procedure for the bank to seek reimbursement for costs is outlined, referencing the Right to Financial Privacy Act, indicating the subpoena targets an individual's or small partnership's records (as corporate records are not reimbursable).
